class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">iStock/Getty Images</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-103l8m3"><div class="css-1e2jphy epjyd6m1"><div class="css-233int epjyd6m0"><p class="css-4anu6l e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemProp="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/natasha-singer" class="css-n8ff4n e1jsehar0">Natasha Singer</a></span></p><div id="enhanced-byline" class="css-8atqhb"><p class="css-m7kxl4 e1wtpvyy0">Natasha Singer covers children’s online privacy and tech regulation.</p></div></div></div></div><div data-testid="reading-time-module"><div class="css-3xqm5e"><time dateTime="2023-10-13T10:26:25-04:00" class="css-8blifj e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">Published <!-- -->Oct. 12, 2023</span><span class="css-233int e16638kd4">Updated <!-- -->Oct. 13, 2023, <span class="css-epvm6">10:26 a.m. ET</span></span></time></div></div></header><div id="NYT_ABOVE_MAIN_CONTENT_REGION" data-testid="region"></div><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Last fall, California lawmakers passed a sweeping online children’s privacy law aimed at regulating how some of the most popular social media and video game platforms treat minors.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Many children’s groups heralded <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/09/15/business/newsom-california-children-online-safety.html" title="">the measure, the first of its kind</a> in the United States. So did Gov. Gavin Newsom. “We’re taking aggressive action in California to protect the health and well-being of our kids,” he said in an statement at the time.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But last month, after a lawsuit filed by a tech industry group whose members include Meta and TikTok, a federal judge in California preliminarily blocked the law, saying <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://netchoice.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/NETCHOICE-v-BONTA-PRELIMINARY-INJUNCTION-GRANTED.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">it “likely violates”</a> the First Amendment.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The judge’s decision was a blow to lawmakers, governors, children’s groups and parents across the United States hoping to curb the lure that platforms like TikTok, Instagram and YouTube hold for many children and teenagers. It was the latest courtroom setback for backers of new state laws designed to limit how online services are allowed to interact with young people.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In August, a federal judge in Arkansas temporarily <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.arkleg.state.ar.us/Home/FTPDocument?path=%2FACTS%2F2023R%2FPublic%2FACT689.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">blocked a new law</a> in that state that would require certain social media platforms to verify the ages of their users and obtain parental consent before allowing minors to create accounts.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">In April, Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders of Arkansas signed a bill requiring certain social media platforms to verify the ages of their users.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Thomas Metthe/Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, via Associated Press</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">That same month, a federal judge in Texas temporarily blocked a new anti-pornography law that would restrict access to content deemed harmful to minors. It would require sexually explicit sites to verify that their users were 18 or older and display health warnings before allowing users to see content.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Some legislators and state officials behind the new social media and pornography age-verification laws said they expected to hit temporary roadblocks. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, the Supreme Court <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/30/business/aclu-free-speech-online.html" title="">overturned similar laws intended to shield children</a> online, saying they could hinder adults and young people from having access to large parts of the internet.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But the legislators behind the California law, the California Age-Appropriate Design Code Act, designed their measure differently. It does not require age verification. It requires online services to design their sites and apps to minimize potential risks for younger users — like exposing them to explicit content or using powerful techniques that prod them to spend hours on end online.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">The California Assembly floor at the Capitol in Sacramento. Last month, a federal judge preliminarily blocked a state law aimed at regulating how social media and video game platforms treat minors.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Jason Henry for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“It’s concerning that as children’s advocates we’re so outgunned just to get legislation passed, and then to have the judge side with more well-financed industry arguments,” said Josh Golin, the executive director of Fairplay, a nonprofit children’s group that backed the California law.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The effort to shield children online is a microcosm of a much larger battle to control the future of the internet. It pits tech giants, tech trade groups and free speech activists against activist governors, lawmakers, progressive children’s groups and conservative parents’ rights groups.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Even the U.S. surgeon general has weighed in. In <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.hhs.gov/about/news/2023/05/23/surgeon-general-issues-new-advisory-about-effects-social-media-use-has-youth-mental-health.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">a recent report</a>, he urged policymakers to strengthen age minimums and “further limit access” to social media “for all children.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">While some members of Congress are still pushing for federal bills to insulate children online, state legislators have passed measures at an astonishing pace. This year, Republican-led states, including <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/12/technology/red-states-montana-tiktok-ban.html" title="">Utah and Arkansas, have passed at least 10 laws</a> restricting minors’ access to social media and online porn sites. Democratic-led states, including California, have also passed new social media laws.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The lawsuit over the California children’s privacy law could have wide repercussions for many other states that have enacted or are pursuing tech regulations.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The case was brought last year by NetChoice, a tech industry group whose members include Amazon, Google and Snap. In its complaint, the group argued that the measure would hinder the free speech rights of companies to publish information online. (The New York Times and the Student Press Law Center jointly filed a <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://netchoice.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/56-1-NYT-and-SPLC-Amicus-Brief.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">friend-of-the-court brief</a> in the case.)</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Chris Marchese, the director of NetChoice’s litigation center, said the law — which requires online services to minimize harm to minors — essentially meant that tech companies would need to sanitize the internet on behalf of young people. He added that restrictive age-verification laws passed in other states could have similar effects.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">NetChoice has also sued to stop the law in Arkansas requiring age verification and parental consent for minors to create social media accounts.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The California law,<em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> “</em>if it were to take effect, would allow the attorney general to go after platforms that don’t remove harmful speech,” Mr. Marchese said. “Where in Texas, they might go after platforms for allowing minors to access content related to trans rights or to transitioning or to L.G.B.T.Q. issues or to abortion issues.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Backers of the California children’s privacy law strongly disagreed. They noted that the measure required online services to turn on the highest privacy settings by default for children. And they argued that the measure regulated product features, not free speech.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“The ruling is profoundly disappointing,” said Jordan Cunningham, a former California state representative who co-sponsored the bill. The law “doesn’t restrict access to content,” he added. It tells online platforms “what privacy settings they’ve got to have.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-1vxyf6h e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:580px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Jordan Cunningham is a former California state representative who co-sponsored the California Age-Appropriate Design Code Act.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Mike Blake/Reuters</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">For now, at least, judges have sided with industry groups on free speech grounds and blocked the California law, along with the new anti-pornography law in Texas and the new social media law in Arkansas, through preliminary injunctions.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div></div></div></section><div class="bottom-of-article"><div class="css-ddxw8g"><div class="css-acwcvw"><strong class="css-1vg6q84">A correction was made on</strong> <div class="css-qa33yi e16638kd1">Oct. 13, 2023</div>: <p class="css-o5w3xl evys1bk0">An earlier version of this article misstated the name of a nonprofit children’s group that backed California’s online children’s privacy law. It is Fairplay, not Fairplay for Kids.</p></div><p>How we handle corrections</p></div><div class="css-1jp38cr"><div class="css-cw8msf eqi4ubu0"><div class="css-kzd6pg"><p><span class=css-97bxx6><a class="authorPageLinkClass overrideLinkStyles" href=https://www.nytimes.com/by/natasha-singer>Natasha Singer</a></span> writes about technology, business and society. She is currently reporting on the far-reaching ways that tech companies and their tools are reshaping public schools, higher education and job opportunities.<span class=css-kzd6pg> <a class="authorPageLinkClass overrideLinkStyles" href=https://www.nytimes.com/by/natasha-singer>More about Natasha Singer</a></span></p></div></div></div><div class="css-13ldwoe">A version of this e1mu4ftr0"/><ul><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0">A growing number of TikTok food stars are using their online clout to break into the publishing world — and <a the best-seller lists with their cookbooks</a>.</p></li><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0">TikTok, which has cemented itself as an advertising venue for brands aiming to reach its young users, is hoping to add a major new revenue stream <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/09/12/business/tiktok-shop-e-commerce.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-tiktok&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">with its own marketplace</a>.</p></li><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0">The social media app, which is known for its short-form videos, will now allow users to <a posts that contain only words</a>, competing with Threads and Twitter.</p></li><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0">The personalities of MovieTok are <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/15/movies/tiktok-movie-reviews-critics.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-tiktok&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">not critics in the traditional sense</a>. Their upbeat videos earn them contracts with Hollywood studios in addition to the devotion of movie lovers. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/15/movies/tiktok-movie-reviewers.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-tiktok&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">Here are eight accounts to know</a>.</p></li><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0">Americans <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/08/style/europe-water-drinking-tiktok.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-tiktok&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">are taking to TikTok to complain</a> that drinking water is impossible to come by in Europe. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, the Supreme Court ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"overturned similar laws intended to shield children","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F04\u002F30\u002Fbusiness\u002Faclu-free-speech-online.html","title":"","uri":null}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" online, saying they could hinder adults and young people from having access to large parts of the internet.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":true,"index":7,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"But the legislators behind the California law, the California Age-Appropriate Design Code Act, designed their measure differently. People are on the bottom floor as well as on the balcony level.","__typename":"Image"}},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":9,"bad":true},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“It’s concerning that as children’s advocates we’re so outgunned just to get legislation passed, and then to have the judge side with more well-financed industry arguments,” said Josh Golin, the executive director of Fairplay, a nonprofit children’s group that backed the California law.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":10,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The effort to shield children online is a microcosm of a much larger battle to control the future of the internet. It pits tech giants, tech trade groups and free speech activists against activist governors, lawmakers, progressive children’s groups and conservative parents’ rights groups.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":false,"index":11,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Even the U.S. surgeon general has weighed in. In ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"a recent report","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.hhs.gov\u002Fabout\u002Fnews\u002F2023\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fsurgeon-general-issues-new-advisory-about-effects-social-media-use-has-youth-mental-health.html","title":"","uri":null}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":", he urged policymakers to strengthen age minimums and “further limit access” to social media “for all children.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":12,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"While some members of Congress are still pushing for federal bills to insulate children online, state legislators have passed measures at an astonishing pace. Democratic-led states, including California, have also passed new social media laws.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":13,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The lawsuit over the California children’s privacy law could have wide repercussions for many other states that have enacted or are pursuing tech regulations.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":14,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The case was brought last year by NetChoice, a tech industry group whose members include Amazon, Google and Snap. In its complaint, the group argued that the measure would hinder the free speech rights of companies to publish information online. (The New York Times and the Student Press Law Center jointly filed a ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"friend-of-the-court brief","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fnetchoice.org\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2023\u002F05\u002F56-1-NYT-and-SPLC-Amicus-Brief.pdf","title":"","uri":null}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" in the case.)","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":true,"index":15,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Chris Marchese, the director of NetChoice’s litigation center, said the law — which requires online services to minimize harm to minors — essentially meant that tech companies would need to sanitize the internet on behalf of young people. He added that restrictive age-verification laws passed in other states could have similar effects.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":16,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"NetChoice has also sued to stop the law in Arkansas requiring age verification and parental consent for minors to create social media accounts.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":17,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The California law,","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" “","formats":[{"__typename":"ItalicFormat","type":null}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"if it were to take effect, would allow the attorney general to go after platforms that don’t remove harmful speech,” Mr. Marchese said. “Where in Texas, they might go after platforms for allowing minors to access content related to trans rights or to transitioning or to L.G.B.T.Q. issues or to abortion issues.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":18,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Backers of the California children’s privacy law strongly disagreed. They noted that the measure required online services to turn on the highest privacy settings by default for children. And they argued that the measure regulated product features, not free speech.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":false,"index":19,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“The ruling is profoundly disappointing,” said Jordan Cunningham, a former California state representative who co-sponsored the bill. oembed.title: New Laws on Kids and Social Media Are Stymied by Industry Lawsuits
oembed.summary: Federal judges in three states have blocked children’s privacy and parental oversight laws, saying they very likely violate free speech rights.

readabilityObject.title: New Laws on Kids and Social Media Are Stymied by Industry Lawsuits
readabilityObject.content:
Advertisement

SKIP ADVERTISEMENT

Federal judges in three states have blocked children’s privacy and parental oversight laws, saying they very likely violate free speech rights.

Natasha Singer

Natasha Singer covers children’s online privacy and tech regulation.

Published Oct. 12, 2023Updated Oct. 13, 2023, 10:26 a.m. ET

Last fall, California lawmakers passed a sweeping online children’s privacy law aimed at regulating how some of the most popular social media and video game platforms treat minors.

Many children’s groups heralded the measure, the first of its kind in the United States. So did Gov. Gavin Newsom. “We’re taking aggressive action in California to protect the health and well-being of our kids,” he said in an statement at the time.

But last month, after a lawsuit filed by a tech industry group whose members include Meta and TikTok, a federal judge in California preliminarily blocked the law, saying it “likely violates” the First Amendment.

The judge’s decision was a blow to lawmakers, governors, children’s groups and parents across the United States hoping to curb the lure that platforms like TikTok, Instagram and YouTube hold for many children and teenagers. It was the latest courtroom setback for backers of new state laws designed to limit how online services are allowed to interact with young people.

In August, a federal judge in Arkansas temporarily blocked a new law in that state that would require certain social media platforms to verify the ages of their users and obtain parental consent before allowing minors to create accounts.

That same month, a federal judge in Texas temporarily blocked a new anti-pornography law that would restrict access to content deemed harmful to minors. It would require sexually explicit sites to verify that their users were 18 or older and display health warnings before allowing users to see content.

Some legislators and state officials behind the new social media and pornography age-verification laws said they expected to hit temporary roadblocks. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, the Supreme Court overturned similar laws intended to shield children online, saying they could hinder adults and young people from having access to large parts of the internet.

But the legislators behind the California law, the California Age-Appropriate Design Code Act, designed their measure differently. It does not require age verification. It requires online services to design their sites and apps to minimize potential risks for younger users — like exposing them to explicit content or using powerful techniques that prod them to spend hours on end online.

“It’s concerning that as children’s advocates we’re so outgunned just to get legislation passed, and then to have the judge side with more well-financed industry arguments,” said Josh Golin, the executive director of Fairplay, a nonprofit children’s group that backed the California law.

The effort to shield children online is a microcosm of a much larger battle to control the future of the internet. It pits tech giants, tech trade groups and free speech activists against activist governors, lawmakers, progressive children’s groups and conservative parents’ rights groups.

Even the U.S. surgeon general has weighed in. In a recent report, he urged policymakers to strengthen age minimums and “further limit access” to social media “for all children.”

While some members of Congress are still pushing for federal bills to insulate children online, state legislators have passed measures at an astonishing pace. This year, Republican-led states, including Utah and Arkansas, have passed at least 10 laws restricting minors’ access to social media and online porn sites. Democratic-led states, including California, have also passed new social media laws.

The lawsuit over the California children’s privacy law could have wide repercussions for many other states that have enacted or are pursuing tech regulations.

The case was brought last year by NetChoice, a tech industry group whose members include Amazon, Google and Snap. In its complaint, the group argued that the measure would hinder the free speech rights of companies to publish information online. (The New York Times and the Student Press Law Center jointly filed a friend-of-the-court brief in the case.)

Chris Marchese, the director of NetChoice’s litigation center, said the law — which requires online services to minimize harm to minors — essentially meant that tech companies would need to sanitize the internet on behalf of young people. He added that restrictive age-verification laws passed in other states could have similar effects.

NetChoice has also sued to stop the law in Arkansas requiring age verification and parental consent for minors to create social media accounts.

The California law, “if it were to take effect, would allow the attorney general to go after platforms that don’t remove harmful speech,” Mr. Marchese said. “Where in Texas, they might go after platforms for allowing minors to access content related to trans rights or to transitioning or to L.G.B.T.Q. issues or to abortion issues.”

Backers of the California children’s privacy law strongly disagreed. They noted that the measure required online services to turn on the highest privacy settings by default for children. And they argued that the measure regulated product features, not free speech.

“The ruling is profoundly disappointing,” said Jordan Cunningham, a former California state representative who co-sponsored the bill. The law “doesn’t restrict access to content,” he added. It tells online platforms “what privacy settings they’ve got to have.”

For now, at least, judges have sided with industry groups on free speech grounds and blocked the California law, along with the new anti-pornography law in Texas and the new social media law in Arkansas, through preliminary injunctions.

A correction was made on

Oct. 13, 2023

: 

An earlier version of this article misstated the name of a nonprofit children’s group that backed California’s online children’s privacy law. It is Fairplay, not Fairplay for Kids.

How we handle corrections

Natasha Singer writes about technology, business and society. She is currently reporting on the far-reaching ways that tech companies and their tools are reshaping public schools, higher education and job opportunities. More about Natasha Singer

A version of this article appears in print on  , Section

B

, Page

4

of the New York edition

with the headline:

Tech Lawsuits Stymie Laws On Kids and Social Media. Order Reprints | Today’s Paper | Subscribe

It requires online services to design their sites and apps to minimize potential risks for younger users — like exposing them to explicit content or using powerful techniques that prod them to spend hours on end online.ImageThe California Assembly floor at the Capitol in Sacramento. Last month, a federal judge preliminarily blocked a state law aimed at regulating how social media and video game platforms treat minors.Credit...Jason Henry for The New York Times“It’s concerning that as children’s advocates we’re so outgunned just to get legislation passed, and then to have the judge side with more well-financed industry arguments,” said Josh Golin, the executive director of Fairplay, a nonprofit children’s group that backed the California law.The effort to shield children online is a microcosm of a much larger battle to control the future of the internet. It pits tech giants, tech trade groups and free speech activists against activist governors, lawmakers, progressive children’s groups and conservative parents’ rights groups.Even the U.S. surgeon general has weighed in. In a recent report, he urged policymakers to strengthen age minimums and “further limit access” to social media “for all children.”While some members of Congress are still pushing for federal bills to insulate children online, state legislators have passed measures at an astonishing pace. This year, Republican-led states, including Utah and Arkansas, have passed at least 10 laws restricting minors’ access to social media and online porn sites. Democratic-led states, including California, have also passed new social media laws.The lawsuit over the California children’s privacy law could have wide repercussions for many other states that have enacted or are pursuing tech regulations.The case was brought last year by NetChoice, a tech industry group whose members include Amazon, Google and Snap. In its complaint, the group argued that the measure would hinder the free speech rights of companies to publish information online. (The New York Times and the Student Press Law Center jointly filed a friend-of-the-court brief in the case.)Chris Marchese, the director of NetChoice’s litigation center, said the law — which requires online services to minimize harm to minors — essentially meant that tech companies would need to sanitize the internet on behalf of young people. He added that restrictive age-verification laws passed in other states could have similar effects.NetChoice has also sued to stop the law in Arkansas requiring age verification and parental consent for minors to create social media accounts.The California law, “if it were to take effect, would allow the attorney general to go after platforms that don’t remove harmful speech,” Mr. Marchese said. “Where in Texas, they might go after platforms for allowing minors to access content related to trans rights or to transitioning or to L.G.B.T.Q. issues or to abortion issues.”Backers of the California children’s privacy law strongly disagreed. They noted that the measure required online services to turn on the highest privacy settings by default for children. And they argued that the measure regulated product features, not free speech.“The ruling is profoundly disappointing,” said Jordan Cunningham, a former California state representative who co-sponsored the bill. The law “doesn’t restrict access to content,” he added. It tells online platforms “what privacy settings they’ve got to have.”ImageJordan Cunningham is a former California state representative who co-sponsored the California Age-Appropriate Design Code Act.Credit...Mike Blake/ReutersFor now, at least, judges have sided with industry groups on free speech grounds and blocked the California law, along with the new anti-pornography law in Texas and the new social media law in Arkansas, through preliminary injunctions.A correction was made onOct. 13, 2023: An earlier version of this article misstated the name of a nonprofit children’s group that backed California’s online children’s privacy law. It is Fairplay, not Fairplay for Kids.How we handle correctionsNatasha Singer writes about technology, business and society. She is currently reporting on the far-reaching ways that tech companies and their tools are reshaping public schools, higher education and job opportunities. More about Natasha SingerA version of this article appears in print on  , Section B, Page 4 of the New York edition with the headline: Tech Lawsuits Stymie Laws On Kids and Social Media.
